snippet: When the housing market collapsed, so did the boom of the outer suburbs where growth had been fastest before the recession. The tentative economic recovery has not led to a revival.
abstract: Editorial welcomes the receding of outer suburbs, or exurbs, which exploded between 2000 and 2010 but collapsed with the housing crisis; notes that the cost of large-scale suburban sprawl is traffic congestion, environmental degradation and increasing addiction to fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: When the housing market collapsed, so did the boom of the outer suburbs where growth had been fastest before the recession. The tentative economic recovery has not led to a revival.
